intro: Liparia boucheri, commonly known as the Boucher's liparia, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils at high altitudes, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions. Its flowers, which bloom in late spring or early summer, are usually white or pale green, and it is often found in alpine meadows. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Liparia boucheri is considered a rare and specialized species.
